Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Analysis of Spatial Cancer Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Successful prevention, early detection, and treatment of cancer requires an understanding of the underlying mechanisms by which cancer evolves spatially and temporally. The occurrence of different cell types in different parts of a tumor, the spatial heterogeneity of the tumor, can lead to failure of therapy that is directed only against one type of cancer cell. Furthermore, spatial heterogeneity is associated with a worse prognosis in many cancer types, and the spatial distribution of nutrients and oxygen can favor the development of more aggressive tumor cell populations. By analyzing spatial cancer models, this research will provide new insights into the mechanistic underpinnings of intra-tumor heterogeneity in solid tumors, and into the role of cellular mobility in shaping tumor phenotypes with poor prognosis. To guarantee that the results are relevant to treatment, the project will be carried out in collaboration with physicians and a cancer biologist. The involvement of graduate students in this research will enhance their ability to work at the interface between mathematics and biology.

This project addresses critical challenges in the quest for more effective diagnostic tools and therapeutic approaches in the fight against cancer. Complex agent-based models have often been employed to investigate the impact of space on cancer evolution. However, even if a simulation successfully reproduces observed phenomena, it does not mean that the true underlying mechanism has been found. For this project the investigators plan to extend prior work on spatial Moran models by adding new features to the basic model. To further reduce the gap between analytically tractable and complex computational models, the behavior of the new systems will be analyzed mathematically. The biological questions to be addressed by the project are motivated by recent experimental findings, including studies of the impact of cancer cell migration on solid tumor growth and elucidation of the role of cancer stem cells in driving cancer evolution. Mathematical models that can include genomic data will be used to study genealogies and intra-tumor heterogeneity in colon cancer. Rigorous results for hybrid models that describe tumor-microenvironment interactions will also be derived. More generally, the rigorous analyses of the models will require the development of novel mathematical techniques that will contribute to a deeper understanding of spatial stochastic systems and the behavior of genealogies in an expanding population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In our research we use mathematical methods to address important biological problems. Mathematics can make inferences about mechanisms over time scales much longer than what can be seen in experiment and can investigate potential therapies. An example of the last type of research is;

Anne Talkington, Claudia Dantoin, and Rick Durrett ODE models of adoptive immunotherapy Published in a special issue of Bulletin Mathematical Biology devoted to Mathematical Oncology 80 (5), 1059-1083

 Modified T cells that have been engineered to recognize the CD19 surface marker have recently been shown to be very successful at treating acute lymphocytic leukemias. In this paper we explored four previous approaches that have used ordinary differential equations to the model this type of therapy, compare their properties, and modify the models to address their deficiencies. Although the four models treat the workings of the immune system in slightly different ways, they all predict that adoptive immunotherapy can be successful to move a patient from the large tumor fixed point to an equilibrium with little or no tumor.

 This paper has been cited 15 times which is not bad for a paper published in 2018. What is more impressive is that it is one of the top 10 most downloaded papers for BMB for all time.

 A second theme in our research was the development of mathematical models that can be used to interpret genomic and epigenomic data obtained from multiple regions of a tumor. In this research, we first developed detailed models of how colorectal cancers grow from one cell into a clinically diagnosed tumor. In a second step we worked with our experimental collaborators to measure the spatial patterns of mutations found in human colorectal cancers through deep sequencing of multiple small areas of individual tumors. Finally, we combined the models with the data to figure out what the most likely cellular dynamics early on during growth. Through this process, we figured out that the studied colorectal cancers didn?t evolve stepwise through the accumulation of increasingly malignant mutations, as was previously assumed. Instead, we found that (i) abnormal cell mobility that is eventually needed for invasion and metastasis is already expressed at the start of growth for some malignant tumors but not benign tumors; (ii) co-evolving subclones with similar malignant potential are common which in turn suggests that barriers to invasion are minimal during growth; (iii) early tumor cells are poised for rapid growth, phenotypic adaptation and immune evasion. Together these findings suggest that many invasive colorectal cancers are born to be bad: their cells move invade and metastasize early on during the growth process.

 A third theme of our research has been evolutionary games, a topic that pprovides novel insights into cancer. In using a game formulation we are not saying that cancer cells choose a strategy, just that cells that choose an advantageous strategy grow faster. Most of the theory has been developed for homogeneously mixing systems, but as Durrett and Levin demonstrated many years ago, space alters the outcome of competition.

 Earlier work of Durrett, Spatial evolutionary games with small selection coefficients. Electronic J. Probability. volume 19 (2014), paper 121, created the beginnings of the theory which can be used to treat all 2x2 games but recently Mridu Nanda and Rick Durrett (2017) Spatial evolutionary games with weak selection. Proceedings of the National Academy of Science. 114, 6046-6051 has extended the theory to predict the behavior of all 3 x 3 games, which encompases most of the examples have been studied.

 Marc Ryser and Kevin Murgas (2017) developed an Evolutionary game model of bone remodeling. Journal of Theoretical Biology, 418(7):16-26. Bone remodeling is a complex process involving cell-cell interactions. Their three-species evolutionary game describes the spatial interactions between zones of bone resorption, bone formation and quiescent bone, and explicitly accounts for regulation of remodeling by bone-embedded, mechanotransducing osteocytes. they systematically classified the different dynamic regimes of the spatial model and identified regions of parameter space that allow for global coexistence of resorption, formation and quiescence, as observed in physiological remodeling. Comparison between spatial and non-spatial dynamics revealed substantial differences and suggested a stabilizing role of space.

The intellectual merit of the proposal consists of the new mathemaitcal methods that were created for these applications. An important part of the broader impacts are the contributions to the understanding of colon cancer, evolutionary games and adoptive immunotherapy. A second significnt broader impact is the training of two graduate students Ruibo Ma, and Hwai-Ray Tung to work at the interface of math and biology. In addition undergraduates Kevin Murgas, Mridu Nanda, Anne Talkington, Claudia Dantoin, Tyler Lian, Zhouqun Wang, Molly Borowiak, FayfayNing, Justin Pei, and Sarah Zhao had an experience of using mathematics to get insights into questions in biology.
